A nation that prides itself for driving global innovation and growth should lend a hand when some in the workforce finds themselves trapped in a way that severely limits their ability to contribute and live a life of dignity and decency.
We should try and lift up all Americans who seek to better themselves and increase their contributions to our nation.

Let‚Äôs not let partisan politics weaponize dialogue about education. This isn‚Äôt about those who seek higher education against those who chose different paths; or those who paid off their loans against those still trying.

Costs are completely out of control. We owe it to our students to take real action to solve these structural problems. In the meantime we need to provide some relief for those trying to pay off debts but are trapped by sky-high interest rates that never let them get on their feet

But we cannot focus solely on how to pay for education in America. We also as a nation must come to grips with the fundamental question of why higher education in this country costs so much to start with?

Interest rates should be as low as possible to give students the benefits of opportunities that their education sought to unlock. We should provide possibilities to restructure and refinance, and substantially increase Pell Grants and other sources of support.

We push young people to be the best and brightest. We boast about having the best schools in the world. But we say ‚Äútough luck‚Äù when students are drowning under the costs? The process of student loans in our country is broken and must be fundamentally fixed.
